item.title: Tidy Tuesday 4-9-18
item.description:
library(tidyverse)
library(magrittr)

Read data into R

rawData <- readxl::read_excel("../../static/data/tidy_tuesday_week2.xlsx")
rawData
## # A tibble: 800 x 11
##     year Cornerback `Defensive Lineman` Linebacker `Offensive Lineman`
##    <dbl>      <dbl>               <dbl>      <dbl>               <dbl>
##  1  2011   11265916            17818000   16420000            15960000
##  2  2011   11000000            16200000   15623000            12800000
##  3  2011   10000000            12476000   11825000            11767500
##  4  2011   10000000            11904706   10083333            10358200
##  5  2011   10000000            11762782   10020000            10000000
##  6  2011    9244117            11340000    8150000             9859166
##  7  2011    8000000            10000000    7812500             9500000
##  8  2011    7900000             9482500    7700000             9420000
##  9  2011    7400000             8450000    7200000             8880000
## 10  2011    7000000             8383266    7100000             8686750
## # ... with 790 more rows, and 6 more variables: Quarterback <dbl>,
## #   `Running Back` <dbl>, Safety <dbl>, `Special Teamer` <dbl>, `Tight
## #   End` <dbl>, `Wide Receiver` <dbl>

Check for missing values

rawData %>% 
  select_if(~any(is.na(.))) %>% 
  summarise_all(~sum(is.na(.)))
## Warning: package 'bindrcpp' was built under R version 3.4.3
## # A tibble: 1 x 2
##   Quarterback `Special Teamer`
##         <int>            <int>
## 1          55                1

How many missing per year per field position?

rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~sum(is.na(.)))
## # A tibble: 8 x 11
##    year Cornerback `Defensive Lineman` Linebacker `Offensive Lineman`
##   <dbl>      <int>               <int>      <int>               <int>
## 1  2011          0                   0          0                   0
## 2  2012          0                   0          0                   0
## 3  2013          0                   0          0                   0
## 4  2014          0                   0          0                   0
## 5  2015          0                   0          0                   0
## 6  2016          0                   0          0                   0
## 7  2017          0                   0          0                   0
## 8  2018          0                   0          0                   0
## # ... with 6 more variables: Quarterback <int>, `Running Back` <int>,
## #   Safety <int>, `Special Teamer` <int>, `Tight End` <int>, `Wide
## #   Receiver` <int>

So…Quartback data is missing values compared to others, but max # missing values for any year across all positions is…

rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~sum(is.na(.))) %>% .[, 2:11] %>% max
## [1] 12

Find Max and Min values per year per field position

maxData <- rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~max(.[!is.na(.)]))
minData <- rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~min(.[!is.na(.)]))
b <- rawData %>% tidyr::gather(`Field Position`, Salary, -year)
b %<>% drop_na(Salary)

Let’s take look at the distribution of the data

ggplot(b) +
    facet_wrap(~year)+
    geom_violin(aes(y = Salary, x = `Field Position`))+
    theme(axis.text.x=element_blank()) +
    xlab("Years") +
    ylab("Salary")

ggplot(b) + 
    facet_wrap(~`Field Position`)+
    geom_boxplot(aes(y = Salary, x = as.factor(year)))+
    theme(axis.text.x=element_blank()) +
    xlab("Years") +
    ylab("Salary")

c <- maxData %>% tidyr::gather(`Field Position`, Salary, -year)
c %<>% drop_na(Salary)
d <- minData %>% tidyr::gather(`Field Position`, Salary, -year)
d %<>% drop_na(Salary)

colnames(b) <- c("Year", "Field Position", "Salary")
colnames(c) <- c("Year", "Field Position", "Salary")
colnames(d) <- c("Year", "Field Position", "Salary")
ggplot(c) + 
    facet_grid(~`Field Position`)+
    geom_line(data=c, aes(x=`Year`, y=`Salary`, colour=`Field Position`), lwd=1.5, alpha = .55)+
    geom_line(data=d, aes(x=`Year`, y=`Salary`, colour=`Field Position`), lwd=1.5, alpha = .55)+
    geom_jitter(data=b, aes(x=`Year`, y=`Salary`, colour=`Field Position`), lwd=1.5, alpha = .15)+
    scale_colour_discrete(guide = FALSE) +
    scale_y_continuous(labels=function(n){format(n, scientific = FALSE)})+
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = .5))+
    labs(title= "Summary Plot os Salaries: \n Max (Lines), Min (Lines), All Values (Points)")+
    theme(plot.title=element_text(hjust=0.5))   

kermit <- rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~moments::skewness(.[!is.na(.)]))

kermit<- kermit %>% tidyr::gather(`Field Position`, Salary, -year)


kermit %<>% drop_na(Salary)


ggplot(kermit) + 
    facet_grid(~`Field Position`)+
    geom_point(aes(x=year, y=Salary, colour=`Field Position`))+
    geom_line(aes(x=year, y=Salary, colour=`Field Position`), lwd=1.5, alpha=.5)+  
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = .5))+
    xlab("Years") +
    ylab("Salary Skew")+
    labs(title= "Stalled Salaries Aren't the Only Issue for Running Backs, \n Skewed Salaries Persist as Well")+
    theme(plot.title=element_text(hjust=0.5))     

kermit <- rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~moments::kurtosis(.[!is.na(.)]))

kermit<- kermit %>% tidyr::gather(`Field Position`, Salary, -year)


kermit %<>% drop_na(Salary)


ggplot(kermit) + 
    facet_grid(~`Field Position`)+
    geom_point(aes(x=year, y=Salary, colour=`Field Position`))+
    geom_line(aes(x=year, y=Salary, colour=`Field Position`), lwd=1.5, alpha=.5)+
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = .5))+
    xlab("Years") +
    ylab("Salary Kurtosis")+
    labs(title= "Stalled Salaries Aren't the Only Issue for Running Backs, \n Skewed Salaries Persist as Well")+
    theme(plot.title=element_text(hjust=0.5))

st <- rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~sd(.[!is.na(.)]))
st <- st %>% tidyr::gather(`Field Position`, Salary, -year)
st %<>% drop_na(Salary)

ggplot(st) + 
    facet_grid(~`Field Position`)+
    geom_point(aes(x=year, y=Salary, colour=`Field Position`))+
    geom_line(aes(x=year, y=Salary, colour=`Field Position`), lwd=1.5, alpha=.5)+
    labs(title="Increasing Salary Standard Deviations Over Time")+
    theme(plot.title=element_text(hjust=0.5))+
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = .5))

sessionInfo()
## R version 3.4.2 (2017-09-28)
## Platform: x86_64-w64-mingw32/x64 (64-bit)
## Running under: Windows 10 x64 (build 16299)
## 
## Matrix products: default
## 
## locale:
## [1] LC_COLLATE=English_United States.1252 
## [2] LC_CTYPE=English_United States.1252   
## [3] LC_MONETARY=English_United States.1252
## [4] LC_NUMERIC=C                          
## [5] LC_TIME=English_United States.1252    
## 
## attached base packages:
## [1] methods   stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  base     
## 
## other attached packages:
##  [1] bindrcpp_0.2    magrittr_1.5    forcats_0.2.0   stringr_1.2.0  
##  [5] dplyr_0.7.4     purrr_0.2.4     readr_1.1.1     tidyr_0.7.2    
##  [9] tibble_1.4.1    ggplot2_2.2.1   tidyverse_1.2.1
## 
## loaded via a namespace (and not attached):
##  [1] tidyselect_0.2.3   xfun_0.1           reshape2_1.4.3    
##  [4] haven_1.1.0        lattice_0.20-35    colorspace_1.3-2  
##  [7] htmltools_0.3.6    yaml_2.1.16        utf8_1.1.3        
## [10] rlang_0.1.6        pillar_1.0.99.9000 foreign_0.8-69    
## [13] glue_1.2.0         modelr_0.1.1       readxl_1.0.0      
## [16] bindr_0.1          plyr_1.8.4         munsell_0.4.3     
## [19] blogdown_0.5       gtable_0.2.0       cellranger_1.1.0  
## [22] moments_0.14       rvest_0.3.2        psych_1.7.8       
## [25] evaluate_0.10.1    labeling_0.3       knitr_1.18        
## [28] parallel_3.4.2     broom_0.4.3        Rcpp_0.12.16      
## [31] backports_1.1.2    scales_0.5.0       jsonlite_1.5      
## [34] mnormt_1.5-5       hms_0.4.0          digest_0.6.13     
## [37] stringi_1.1.6      bookdown_0.6       grid_3.4.2        
## [40] rprojroot_1.3-2    cli_1.0.0          tools_3.4.2       
## [43] lazyeval_0.2.1     crayon_1.3.4       pkgconfig_2.0.1   
## [46] xml2_1.1.1         lubridate_1.7.1    assertthat_0.2.0  
## [49] rmarkdown_1.8      httr_1.3.1         rstudioapi_0.7    
## [52] R6_2.2.2           nlme_3.1-131       compiler_3.4.2

item.title: A Shiny New World
item.description:
Disclaimer (and maybe dissapointment): This has no connection to Huxley’s dystopian.

Jump to Section:

  • Brief Introduction
  • Example Apps
  • Code and Presentation Slides
  • Resources for Beginners

Introduction

I recently gave a talk at a meetup in Chicago about an R Shiny app I am working on called IDBac. While there are plenty of example apps for Shiny I also wanted to create some examples of my own for now and any future instruction. Since the meetup had some scheduled time for attendees to work in groups or on their own I thought a nice demonstration of Shiny would be an app that could interactively create groups based on a self-reported skill level.

However I also wanted to include some introductory-type apps to cover a range of beginner to intermediate skill levels. So, in all, there are three suggested apps to look through, hopefully with each stepping up a degree in skill level needed for both data-wrangling and Shiny skills. Some links to tutorials and resources can be found at the end of the post.

  • App One
    • Was borrowed from RStudio’s example gallery and should be straightforward enough to learn some of the basics of Shiny as you go through tutorials.
      • Skills: simple data analysis, simple clustering, simple plotting with base R
  • App Two
    • Is based on the GapMinder dataset and includes two static ggplots and an interactive datatable.
      • Skills: simple data analysis, simple plotting with ggplot
  • App Three
    • Is the demonstration app on splitting Meetup attendees into groups. It uses googlesheets, jsonlite to parse API responses, and some more advanced data analysis (both purrr and lapply) and building a dynamic nested HTML table in Shiny.
      • Skills: Parsing API and JSON, googlesheets,dplyr, purrr (map), lapply, dynamic html tags in Shiny There are some challenges/suggestions included in each of the apps.

App One: Beginner Example

I find Joe Cheng’s k-means example to be pretty straightforward to point out the basic features of reactivity and chose this as challenge for beginner’s to get familiar with shiny. Trying to understand what happens when you “break” certain lines of the code and why inputs, outputs, and reactives are placed where they are.


App Two and Three: Beginner/Intermediate Examples


App Two: Plotting GapMinder Data

This example is pretty short and simple with an interactive dataframe and two static ggplots within three separate tabPanels.

There are some challenges/suggestions on the left side of the page. These include making the ggplots interactive.


App Three: Interactively Create Groups at a Meetup

Due to some technical difficulties with the display tech at the meetup I wasn’t able to present this app example since I was using a computer sans-R, but wanted to include it here.

Imagine:

You’re organizing an Rstats workshop through Meetup.com. You have a lot of participants and want to separate them into groups based on self-reported skill levels, how would you accomplish this with Shiny?

Of course there are many ways, but the simplest I thought of was to use Google Forms and connect responses to information retrieved from the Meetup.com API.

  1. First, you would need to setup a Google Form and send it to participants to fill out: Example Google Form here
    • The responses will be recorded into a Google Sheet.
      • For more information on using Google Sheets with R, please see Jenny Bryan and Joanna Zhao’s tutorial.
    • Copy the key for the Google Sheet (eg in bold below below)
      • https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/ 1xxtw88dEKDdQ1CoeLm46FWmNt3bqPSCGp4P7LA7BNv0
    • Find the code snippet below within the shiny app and replace “Insert Key Here” with your key
responses <- reactive({
      surveyResponses <- gs_key(" Insert Key Here ")
      surveyResponses %>%  gs_read(ws = "Form Responses 1")
      
  })
  1. Then create the json API GET request for your Meetup.com event. To do so you would go here, fill out the form, create the API, and copy the Signed URL that is created.
    • Find the code snippet below within the Shiny app and replace “Insert Signed URL Here” with your signed url.
listFromAPI<-read_json(" Insert Signed URL Here ")

Shiny Apps Code and Chicago R User Group Presentation Slides

All three examples, and my presentation, are available on github at: github.com/chasemc/Jan2018ShinyMeetupCRUG or by download as a package with:

# Install devtools if you haven't already
# install.packages(devtools)
devtools::install_github("chasemc/Jan2018ShinyMeetupCRUG")

All three apps are released under the MIT License.

Resources

  • Where to start:
    • swirlstats.com
    • r4ds.had.co.nz
    • Then move on to: adv-r.had.co.nz
  • Where to find answers to your questions:
    • stackexchange.com
    • community.rstudio.com
    • Web Search! (i.e. google.com)
      • E.g. (search: convert list to data frame in R)

And for those new to Shiny:

  • A few Shiny resources:
    • shiny.rstudio.com/tutorial
    • shiny.rstudio.com/articles
    • shiny.rstudio.com/gallery
    • shiny.rstudio.com/gallery/widget-gallery
    • deanattali.com/blog/building-shiny-apps-tutorial
